episode.title: County of Marin v. United States

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 415, County of Marin, County of Contra Costa, Marin County Federation of Commuters Club and the Contra Costa County Commuters versus United States of America.
Mr. Avakian.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: May it please the Court.

This case involves the question of whether the special machinery provided by Congress in Section 5 of the Interstate Commerce Act to encourage consolidations of carriers can be used for the slit up of a single carrier's operations into separate corporations for the purpose of escaping the regulatory policies applied by the State Utility Commission to the essentially intrastate operations involved in the split-up.

It also raises the issue of whether it was an abuse of discretion to deny leave to amend the complaint to challenge the public interest findings of the Interstate Commerce Commission where the original complaint raised only the question of the applicability of the statute and the amendment was offered contemporaneously with the submission of cross-motions for summary judgment.
The issue as to the applicability of Section 5 is of particular significance because of the interplay of federal state relationships in the regulation of local transportation services.
The case is here on appeal from a judgment of a three-judge District Court affirming the order of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

That order, which was rendered in 1955, granted an application by Pacific Greyhound Lines and its newly created subsidiary, Golden Gate Transit Lines, to transfer Greyhound's local San Francisco Bay area operations to the new subsidiary, Golden Gate.
The Interstate Commerce Commission held that Section 5 applied.

This section provides that the transactions for the consolidation or merger or unification of carrier operations, either by acquisition of property or by arrangements for common control, must be first approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
And when so approved may be consummated without regard to the antitrust laws and without the approval of any other federal agency or of any state agency.

If Section 5 does not apply to this transaction, then the Interstate Commerce Commission's authority is limited, under Section 212 (b), to a transfer of the interstate operating rights only and the State Commission would have jurisdiction over the proposed transfer of the intrastate service.
In the District --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What is the service in the San Francisco Bay area?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: This service is in the San Francisco Bay area essentially a commuter service radiating out of San Francisco, a distance of 25 to 30 miles, northward into Marin Country, eastward into Contra Costa Country and southerly into what is known as the Peninsula area.
In the District Court, the original complaint raised only the question of the applicability of Section 5.
Both sides, that is plaintiffs and -- and the Government, made motions for summary judgment.

Greyhound and Golden Gate, as interveners, filed a motion to amend and while those motions came up for argument, the appellants, who are here now, asked to leave to amend their complaint to challenge the public interest findings as well.
The motion to amend was --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where -- I'm sorry I miss something.
Where was this motion to amend (Inaudible) something to make?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: In the District Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In the District Court.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: attorney_general
turn.label: Mr. Attorney General
turn.text: Pardon me.
(Inaudible)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Just -- just a moment -- just a moment please.
You may respond when your time comes.

turn.speaker: attorney_general
turn.label: Mr. Attorney General
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may respond when your time comes.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The denial of the motion to amend was by two of the judges.
One of the members of the Court dissented on the ground that under Rule 15 (a) the amendment should be allowed in the interest of the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I -- may I ask this?
This amendment was to one end?
This is in the District Court, I believe --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- the Commission had acted?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes.
And it was for the purpose of challenging the public interest findings of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was that issue contested before the Commission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Oh, yes, it was.
It was contested before the Commission and it was contested on a petition for rehearing which the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But in the complaint -- in the complaint in which you challenged the order, no objection was made to that aspect of the order and in the District Court, we tried to amend the basis of -- for the extent and scope or the nature of the issues which you challenged, is that all?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) in issue?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Later than that, the only case (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's correct.
On the -- on the Section 5 point, that would control the case finally.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Issue had been joined, Your Honor, by this cross-motions for summary judgment because the complaint raised only the legal question of the applicability of Section 5 but --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: There had been an answer by the United States but not by the interveners.

And I might add at this point that the complaint originally was not only by these appellants who are two commuter associations and two counties, but also joined as plaintiffs originally where the labor unions who represented Greyhound drivers.
The motions for summary judgment and to dismiss were set for argument on February 23rd, 1956.

When they were called, the interveners Greyhound and Golden Gate and the United States offered a dismissal by the labor union plaintiffs on the basis of an agreement which had been reached two days before February 21st.
And that agreement contained the provision that if this transaction were consummated, the labor contract of the unions with the two carriers would be a single labor contract.

This was directly contrary to one of the public interest findings of the Interstate Commerce Commission to the effect that one of the public interest factors which would be served by this separation was the separation of separate labor contracts for each operation and the Commission's order recited that there had been problems in the past by virtue of the fact that Greyhound had to deal with its local drivers in the same bargaining agreements as it did with its intercity drivers.

And when this agreement, which resulted in the dismissal of the labor unions, was presented to the Court at the time the motions came up for argument, we stated to the Court that in view of this development and our reconsideration in the light of that of the issue of public interest, we desired leave to amend the complaint to raise also the issue of whether the evidence supported the public interest findings of the Commission.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Since you fall into this, may I ask this?
At the labor union, for them -- do they -- had they been before the Court?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: As plaintiffs, yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As plaintiffs.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Jointly with us.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And they -- and they raised the public interest question?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: They had raised the public interest question before the Commission --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: -- but not before the Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that although they had objected to the report and the determination of the Commission, they did not in court aline on your side objects to raise the public interest question, is that right?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: They were -- they were exactly with us.
There was a single complaint.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They -- they didn't raise the public interest question.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: And we only raised it after they dismissed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But after they dismiss that the Commission having gone partly on the ground of its desirability, as I understand from you, of having two separate unions for bargaining purposes.
The union itself in its answer did not raise that question but then, you keep it up after they dropped that although they have made no objection, is that right?
Is that a fair statement?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not going any --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: It is essentially correct.
The -- the only thing I'd like to say is that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not drawing any inference.
I just want to know what it is.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The -- the unions were joint plaintiffs with us --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: -- in a single complaint.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) this point?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Neither one of us raised it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that -- so that you -- you then made the point not because they have made them, there -- it was no longer there to raise it.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: We made the point because this agreement as we saw this contrary to the finding of the Commission.

The background of this case, if I may state it very briefly and the background is important because the -- a report of the Interstate Commerce Commission specifically recites that Greyhound's purpose in the slit-up is to escape the rate regulation policies of the California Public Utilities Commission.
The background is essentially this.
I've already stated the area covered.
The population in that area is approximately 400,000 people.
The revenue from this service which is proposed to be split off is approximately $3,700,000 a year.
And of this revenue, 5.7% represents Interstate Commerce and 94.3% represents intrastate commerce.
Greyhound's dissatisfaction with the State Public Utilities Commission is based on several factors.

One is that in establishing rates for this local service, the State Public Utilities Commission has consistently held that Greyhound's revenue needs for this service should be determined in the light of its total intrastate revenues and that as long as Greyhound receives an adequate return in its total intrastate service, it is not entitled to an increase in rates in this particular segment.

And I might say that in its rate decisions, the State Commission has allowed Greyhound a fair rate of return on its intrastate operations in the most recent decision in 1957, a 7.1% rate of return was allowed on the total intrastate service.
In a decision in 1951, dealing with the statewide rates, a 6.4% rate of return was allowed.

In applying this policy, the State Commission takes into consideration the fact that because of the necessity to preserve competition between Greyhound and others in other areas of the State, it is forced to establish rates in the other areas which give Greyhound more than a fair rate of return.
And that windfall is offset in the State Commission's minds by the rates that it establishes in this local service.
And the State Commission also states that it considers the law of diminishing returns with respect to increases in commuter rates and where it has given increases in this particular segment.

It has felt that there was a limiting factor as to the amount of revenue which effectively could be obtained by an increase by reason of the diversion of traffic to carpools and other means of transportation that would result if the increases were too high.
And finally, the carrier here, Greyhound, previously tried to get permission from the State Commission to transfer a portion of this service, the Marin Country portion, to another operator.

And after a lengthy hearing, the State Commission held that the proposed financing of that transfer of a limited segment of this operation was insufficient, even though the transferee was proposing to invest $200,000 working capital in the operation.

In this case, which involve not only Marin but Contra Costa and the Peninsula operation, Greyhound proposed to put into Golden Gate only $150,000 in working capital and the Interstate Commerce Commission conditioned its approval on the sum of only $250,000 as a working capital.

After the Interstate Commerce Commission had rendered its decision in which it rejected the protest made by the labor unions and by the present appellants as to the applicability of Section 5 and as to the public interest, both groups, both the unions and the present appellants filed a petition for rehearing before the Commission in which they again challenged the applicability of Section 5.

They challenged the public interest findings of the Commission and furthermore, they ask for further hearing because of some additional testimony which had been given after the Interstate Commerce Commission's decision.
And I mention this because in the proposed amendment, we seek to charge abuse of discretion on the part of the Interstate Commerce Commission in denying this petition for further hearing.
In the Interstate Commerce Commission proceeding, the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Did the parties challenge (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: At all stages.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: At all stages.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What were the effects of the proposed amendment to be now that were allowed?
Did you go back to the Court and argue exceptions to the findings of the Commission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes.

We would argue the sufficiency of the evidence to support those findings and we would argue the question of abuse of discretion in denying the further hearing in view of the facts which I'm just about to state.
In the Interstate Commerce Commission, the principal Greyhound witness testified that $150,000 cash working capital would be adequate for the subsidiary to perform the services.
This was in the phase of the own showing of the carriers, that the one year's operation would produce a loss of $230,000.

Two weeks after the Interstate Commerce Commission order had been handed down, this same witness, testifying before the State Utilities Commission in a proceeding seeking an increase in rates for the -- for the Marin and Peninsula services, testified that there should be included in the rate base or rate-making purposes, the item of cash working capital in an amount equal to one-twelfth of the annual cash expenditures.
And in the examination in that case, he said most emphatically that this was a necessary working capital.
He even said that a new company would have to provide that much capital.

Now, as applied to this case, that would require a working cash working capital of $321,000 and the petition for rehearing set forth a verbatim transcript of this witness' testimony before the State Commission and asked for further hearing before the I.C.C., which was denied.
The --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That's the new evidence that you referred to?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's the new evidence that -- upon which we asked for reopening, that's right.

And our amendment insofar as it relates to that charges, abuse of discretion in the denial of the hearing because that testimony would be directly contrary, not only to what was testified before the I.C.C., but also would invalidate the I.C.C.'s conclusion that $250,000 in cash working capital would be adequate.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you mean this is new evidence that hadn't been before the Commission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is the provision of the statute, if any, which (Inaudible) the power of the District Court to hear new evidence?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: This is not new evidence which we wanted to present to the District Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You wanted the case to go back to the Commission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: We're charging that the District Court on this phase of it should have held that the Interstate Commerce Commission should reopen the proceeding and take the evidence.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: On the basis of the new evidence facing for it.
You wanted -- you want the District Court's dissent not to decide any of the issues presented back to the Commission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: This was on the basis of new evidence submitted to the Interstate Commerce Commission on the petition for rehearing which was denied.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) that is -- the Commission denied that.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: A very good reason?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: No.
I just simply denied it in order --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: After the case was closed before it.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: It was -- while the time for petition for rehearing was still open.
This testimony that I'm mentioning was given two weeks after the Interstate Commerce Commission handed down.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) How long had the case been before the Commission (Inaudible) been before the Examiner?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The case was heard by the Examiner in April of 1954.
The Examiner rendered his proposed report recommending denial of the application in the fall of 1955 and -- I am sorry, in the fall of 1954.
And thereafter, the entire Commission heard our argument and in July of 1955, issued its order granting the application.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, was -- in your petition for reopening the case, did you lay the ground that this is a newly discovered evidence --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes, we did.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- which is not capable of having been produced during all this time?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes, we did and it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What makes -- why would this -- why was it not available before?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Because it was a testimony given by the principal Greyhound witness given for the first time after the Interstate Commerce Commission decision come down but relating to the very issue of what's necessary working capital for this kind of an operation.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Therefore, would have been useful to you in cross-examining him before the Commission if you -- if you had that -- that if he testified, you -- you have that (Inaudible) is that it?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Not only that, Your Honor, but in the phase of that, since he was the principal Greyhound witness, the Interstate Commerce Commission, if they heard that testimony, could not possibly have concluded that $250,000 would be work-adequate capital.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, this later testimony of his was not capable of having been carried it out by you?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Because it's -- it's something which they speak from their own knowledge.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is -- this was expert evidence?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: This is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Rather available figures.
Well, I just want to know.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: No.
The -- the thing that was not available to us was Greyhound's own judgment as to what is necessary working capital.

And this was the vice president of Greyhound testifying in one case that $150,000 is adequate, testifying in another case where it's to their advantage to build up the rate base that there should be included in the rate base an amount equal to one month's cash expenditures as necessary working capital.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the time period was the same and the conditions were the same?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: It's -- it's essentially the same operation, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's the same operation.
They may well be in this case of fluctuating prices.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: I don't think that the question of what proportion of your expenses you need as cash working capital would be affected by time.
It might be affected by whether they are the same operations or not, but I don't think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: These are ratios and not amount?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When was the testimony given before the I.C.C.that $150,000 would be adequate?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: In April of 1954.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When did he testify (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: No, it -- he testified before the State Commission in July of 1955 and his testimony was that cash working capital had to be in the amount of one-twelfth of the annual cash expenditures.

And that formula, as applied to the showing made in this case before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the basis of the expenses shown to the Interstate Commerce Commission, would be $321,000 cash working capital.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has the Commission found what was -- that was adequate?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And -- and I gather that both proceedings are (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: This very company and almost exactly the same operation.
The State Utility Commission proceeding involved the rates for the Marin and Peninsula services.
These proceeding involved those two plus the Contra Costa County, which is the smaller portion.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, despite -- well, despite present cross-examined before your State Commission regarding his contradictory and so forth on your place, contradicted testimony before the Commission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: He was not -- no.
He was cross-examined as to whether he was sure that you needed this much working capital and he became quite emphatic in saying that you have to have this much.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did your Commission have the -- his testimony before the Interstate Commerce Commission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Well, the -- no, the Commission didn't have it.
This cross-examination, Your Honor, was by myself as counsel for these same people who were appellants here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, then that would be more confounded now.
You were before the Commission, the Interstate Commerce Commission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You heard his testimony?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You knew him?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did you cross-examine him before your State Commission regarding his contradiction?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: I don't believe so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, then, why shouldn't -- why should the I.C.C. a part of the contradiction?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I -- I should think the reliability of a witness is an issue -- is -- is issue that goes to the value of the testimony.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Well, I might say that there -- insofar as reliability of the witness is concern, there was considerable cross-examination on other points in which contradictions had been developed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Not before the State Commission.
No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you did rather use it before the I.C.C., next to the rehearing where it was relevant.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right and it's set forth verbatim in the petition for rehearing filed before the Interstate Commerce Commission and it's in the record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are you saying it wasn't relevant for you to cross-examine him on his inconsistency?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Before the State Commission, it would have been relevant.
Oh, I don't say it's not relevant.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You didn't deem it's relevant.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: There are a lot of things which are relevant in --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: -- cross-examination which the Examiner --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: -- I deem it relevant, but I didn't deem it within the scope of -- of my judgment as to why I should cross-examine him in the context of everything else in which I cross-examine.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If he happened to decide whether the Commission was within its discretionary power in not opening the case, is that right?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Well, no.
No -- no, I don't.
That's -- the question here is whether the lower court should have permitted us to make the amendment to raise this question.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, then, the question before it was, whether the Commission abused its discretion and not reopen the case --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and that's the question here whether the District Court allowably said that that wasn't exercise, not an abuse of discretion, is that right?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: On that branch of it, yes.
And, of course, our men would also challenge the public interest findings --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But that's (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It's certainly as though it states here of a question whether the State Commission (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: No.
No, that is not involved.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that will not -- the outcome here will not determine (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Not in a legal sense.
In a realistic sense, the -- there's a great bearing on rates, of course --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but I understand there --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: -- because in -- in a realistic sense, if the separation goes through, then in an application for rates involving this local service, the only carrier before the State Commission will be the Golden Gate subsidiary.
And this will circumvent what the State Commission has been applying as a policy of considering Greyhound's windfall in the rest of the State in deciding what the rates for this service should be.

Now, I feel -- if the Court please, that this question of whether we should have been permitted to make this amendment in the lower court is effectively controlled by what this Court did just a month ago in Spevack versus Strauss, 355 U.S.601, where in granting certiorari, it directed that the matter be remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions to allow an amendment to the complaint which had been presented there for the first time in the Court of Appeals.
This reflects the liberal rules of pleading set forth in 15 (a) of the Civil Rules.

And certainly, if it was an abuse of discretion for the Court of Appeals to deny an amendment presented for the first time in that Court, then all the more, in our case, where we presented the amendment at the outset of arguments on motions for summary judgment in the District Court, the amendment should have been allowed.
And I might say that the Court took 14 months to deny our motion to amend.
Our motion to amend was made in February of 1956.

It was set down for oral argument in April of 1956 and it was not denied by the District Court until April of 1957, a full 14 months after we filed the motion so that it can -- the action of the lower court can hardly be explained or defended on the ground that it would have unfairly delayed disposition of the case.
The lower court did not contend that the amendment was insubstantial.
On the contrary, it said only that in the absence of a showing of mistake, inadvertence, neglect or changed conditions, the amendment should not be allowed.
These are the criteria which govern the granting of relief from a default judgment and not the criteria which govern the granting of amendments to pleadings.
I pass now to the question of the applicability of Section 5 to split-ups.
The statutory language itself quite clearly shows that split-ups are not contemplated by Section 5.

It sets forth five classes of transactions, and if my telescope the language but read what I read verbatim, the five classes are as follows, and these are set forth on pages 22 and 23 of our main brief, “For two or more carriers to consolidate or merge their properties or franchises into one corporation.
Secondly, for any carrier to purchase lease or contract to operate the properties of another.
Third, for any carrier to acquire control of another.
Fourth, for a person which is not a carrier to acquire control of two or more carriers.
And fifth, for a person which is not a carrier and which has control of one or more carriers to acquire control of another carrier.”
In every instance, we start out with two or more carriers to come within these provisions.
Now, the Commission in the lower court applied the provision -- the third provision, which I read which is, “For any carrier to acquire control of another”.

And the reasoning of the Commission in the lower court was that on the consummation of this transaction, Golden Gate, which is presently not a carrier, will become a carrier once it gets into the operation of the -- of the service which is proposed to be transferred.

It will become a carrier and at that time, it will be controlled by its parent, Greyhound, which is a carrier and therefore, we have claimed by operation bootstrap into a situation of one carrier acquiring control of another carrier.

Not only does this do violence to the language of Section 5, but it is completely inconsistent with the purposes of Section 5 as clearly shown by the legislative history, as this Court has frequently itself set forth in its opinions.
This provision, Section 5, as written into the 1940 Transportation Act had, as its purpose, the provision of means of relief for a very sick transportation industry.

In the 1920 Act, which was passed when the Government was turning the operation of the railroad back to the companies, Congress had decided upon the approach of imposing on the Interstate Commerce Commission the obligation to formulate plans of consolidation of railroads into a relatively few systems.

And once the Commission formulated and announced a consolidation plan, carriers could then initiate mergers and consolidations but that approach never worked because the Commission never got around to formulating a plan of consolidation.
So finally, after lengthy studies by presidential committees and congressional committees, in the 1940 Act, this was all changed.

The obligation on the Commission to formulate plans was removed and carriers were given the authority to initiate voluntarily, merger and consolidation plans subject to the requirement that they must be approved by the Commission as consistent with the public interest.

The Committee Report show that Congress was dealing with an industry which was described as being one-third in bankruptcy and the other third on the verge, and the need for providing effective and practical means of consolidating weak carriers was urgent.

Obviously, in the case particularly of large carriers, mergers and consolidations could not effectively be carried out if the approval were required of every other regulatory agency which might have jurisdiction over any portion of the transaction.

And for that reason, Congress provided that once approved by the Commission, this merger and consolidation plans could be carried out regardless of the antitrust laws and without invoking the approval of any federal agency or of any state agency.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Exactly.
It was to -- in --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: By split-up -- the split-up based in the Committee Reports?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Never.

Every term in this Committee Reports is in the line of merger, consolidation, cooling, unification, combination, acquiring common control, all the language and all of the discussion is in terms of enabling weak carriers to combine.

What Greyhound proposes to do here is to cut off the weak member of its single corporate body and send it out to flounder for itself and very proudly to die in the bankruptcy courts, and to do this under the -- the purported authority of a statute which was designed to encourage just the opposite form --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Has the Commission therefore applied Section 5 to split-up?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Section 5 has been applied to split-ups by the Commission, so far as I know from my own research and briefs of the appellees in five cases.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible) what's the other?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The earliest case is 1940.
The second case is 1940 --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Section 5 is 1920, came in 1920.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Well, the -- in its present form, it came in 1940.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know but it's -- it came in originally and it might be in 1920.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right, yes.
Now, those two cases in 1940 and 1941 are the only Commission cases decided prior to the time when we contested this construction before the Interstate Commerce Commission.
So, the administrative history up to the point where we challenged it in our case consists of these two cases in 1940 and 1941.
Neither of those two cases were they contested proceeding, there was nobody before the Commission objecting to what was being done.

And as our supplemental brief shows in the first of these, the 1940 case, Columbia Terminals, the carriers themselves didn't rely upon the exclusive authority of the Commission but they went to the State Commission and got approval from the State Commission for the transfer of the intrastate right involved.
That's the total administrative interpretation prior to the commencement of our case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Hasn't there been any provision decision at all (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The -- the three decisions since are in 1954, 1956 and 1957.
They likewise involved proceedings in which there was nobody protesting what was being done.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: How they get into court?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: They didn't get into court.
These are all Commission decision.
There are no court decisions.
There's -- there's never been anybody in these Commission proceedings who showed an interest in the matter and who therefore would have been in the position to go into court on this.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Our decisions turned over (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Every decision of this Court and of any other court has been in the field of mergers.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: We -- we don't reach the question which divided the Court there because in that case, you had several existing carriers already under a common control with a proposal to -- to strengthen or increase the control by a -- a merger of some of the controlled entities into the other.

And the question there which divided the Court would whether that transaction constituted an acquisition of control or whether the control had already been acquired by previous transactions.So, we don't reach that question here at all.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: On this question, on this issue, what was the difference between the Act of 1920 about which Justice Brennan asked you and the Transportation Act of 1940?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Insofar as split-ups are concerned?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, in both.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: How?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In regard to the actual content of what is now Section 5.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The 19 --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) as you said it was a supplanting of the provisions.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In 19 -- in 1920 Act, the Transportation Act of 1920, this both case, it both authorized -- made provision for authorization, consolidation and mergers and also directed the Commission to make a comprehensive plan to unify the railroad system.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes, but --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But -- but he sure is paying and therefore, that was cut out in the 1940 amendment.
What I want to know is, what were the changes, the subsequent changes between the authorizations of the 1920 and 1940 Acts in relating to the same subject?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The big change, Your Honor, was that under the 1920 Act, the carriers could not initiate a merger or consolidation unless the Commission had first announced a consolidation plan.
And then, consistently with the announced consolidation plan, carriers could propose mergers consistent with them.
The 1940 Act --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Cut -- cut the first cutout.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Is there anything in the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: In the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: When the Motor Carrier Act was first enacted in 1935, it provided for mergers and consolidations with the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission in pretty much the same language which is contained in the 1940 amendment to Section 5 and at that time the motor carrier provisions were repealed from -- from part two of the Motor Carrier Act and motor carriers were brought under Section 5 along with water carriers and the railroads.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, a railroad, these are motor carriers, a railroad couldn't divest itself as part of its system, could it, without permission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What provision was there to allow divestiture, a part of a railroad system by transferring it to some other railroads?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The -- the divestment by transfer would have had to have been by approval of the Commission in terms of a purchase of one portion of the carrier's property by another carrier.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To that extent, there was a split off provided for or authorized by the Act.
If you're going to use word like “split off,” there was a split off, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The -- this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Whenever there was a divestment of a system of railroads --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: As -- as long as --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) its activities, there's a split off?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: As -- in that sense, yes.

As long as it goes from one carrier to another carrier, it's within Section 5 but the -- the split-up and I use “split-up” rather than “split off” to distinguish that situation, the split-up here does not involve a transfer to some other existing carrier but rather the subdivision of a single carrier into two units.
The vice of this situation --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: My suggest to it -- I suppose you would say in that case there is a -- a merger of the really acquiring road into divesting road.
That's -- that's the difference, isn't it?
But here, there's -- there's an internal separation.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.
This -- this is like an -- an amoeba --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: -- subdividing itself.
Only the amoeba has the protoplasmic quality to create a completely new and independent unit out of its subdivision whereas --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Here -- here, you have to get somebody's permission?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: And -- and here in addition, the segment being cut-off realistically is not going to be able to grow into successful and healthy manhood, but rather, it's being cut-off in -- in such a way that the operation itself is going to be a weak floundering and probably a dying operation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is the conclusion of your contention that if a railroad or motor enterprise would like to cut-off a non-paid aspect, it cannot so rid itself of a vesting asset unless it is able to transfer to an existing parent.
Is that your -- that's what it get down to business.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Yes, with this qualification.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Not state approval?

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That if it gets state approval, it may have been.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I understand.
It's about the Commission people.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: That's right.
It would have to get the approval whatever Commission had jurisdiction over that particular branch or segment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, the Court has rendered some decisions that I respect, but I don't agree with it at the time which made also to (Inaudible) on requirement of state approval.
I'm thinking of Schwabacher case (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not saying that -- that's Schwabacher but I'm -- I'm indicating the attitude of this Court for all those problems, the state-interstate relation.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Well, I think the -- the case which comes closest to applying the philosophy which we think applies here is the decision of this Court last January in the Chicago Commuter case, the Milwaukee Road case in which the Interstate Commerce Commission made an order increasing the intrastate commuter rates on the ground that they constituted -- the existing rates constitute a burden on interstate commerce and this Court held in setting that aside that the finding of that type could not be supported unless the entire intrastate rate structure --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If that was closer --

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: -- was inevitable.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- it's pretty far away so far as I'm concern.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: The -- the factually, of course, is -- is different but the philosophy which the Court express about the need for a scrupulous regard for the State -- interest of the State under the federal system which we have, the philosophy expressed in that opinion applies here in the sense that the Court should not oust the jurisdiction of state agencies under Section 5, unless the transaction is of the type which Section 5 was designed to meet.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, we've got -- those are really different problems.
That's the question on the floor when you display a conceded state rate.
All right.
All I'm saying is, if you say that's the closest, then we've got to make new law here.

turn.speaker: spurgeon_avakian
turn.label: Mr. Spurgeon Avakian
turn.text: Well, I -- I say it's close in -- in the philosophy expressed, not in the issue presented, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Ginnane.

turn.speaker: robert_w_ginnane
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Ginnane
turn.text: May it please the Court.
I would like to first to discuss the facts relating to the posture of this case, what has been properly before the District Court and what we believe is properly before this Court.
Now, the court proceeding began on October 1955 and these appellants filed their complaint and it's in the record of pages 1 to 7.

And on that complaint, they attacked the Commission's orders solely on a single ground that transactions of this type, split-up as they call it, are not subject to the Commission's jurisdiction under Section 5.
Nothing was said in there about the rate, policies to California Commission, nothing about the sufficiency of the Commission's findings, their support on the evidence or anything else.
Simply, the question of whether this type of transaction is covered by Section 5.
As the appellants have stated, thereafter both the appellants and the defendants, United States and Interstate Commerce Commission filed motions for judgment in the pleadings.
It was perfectly clear what everybody was doing.

The appellants stated in their own motion that they so moved for the reason that the pleadings of the various parties showed that there is no question of fact involved in the case and that the sole question recited is one of law.
Plaintiffs did not file to the District Court the record of the evidence received before the Commission.
That evidence is not before this Court.
Then, the case went to argument before the three judges.
And it was only in the course of the oral argument before three federal judges.
Now, for the first time, we'd heard about this proposal to amend the complaint in the course of the argument.

The appellant's counsel stated that he intended, "To," and I quote, "To ask leave of the Court in the event the determination of the Court should be against us on the legal question raised to give us permission to amend the complaint, to set forth as an additional ground the challenge of the finding of the Commission that the order in question is consistent with the public interest".
And not even at that point, if may I point out, not even at that point did he say anything about challenging the Commission's action in refusing to reopen the case for rehearing and reconsideration.
And it was not until February 28, five days after the oral argument before the three-judge court that these appellants filed their motion for leave to amend their complaint.
The District Court heard argument on this motion.
Then on April 12, 1957, the three-judge court handed down its decision.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean there's a separate argument on this after the main argument?

turn.speaker: robert_w_ginnane
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Ginnane
turn.text: Yes, in April 1956.
The three-judge court called us out to -- to argue on whether the motion to amend should be granted.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there any response from the -- from the Court at the time they first mentioned that they wanted to amend the complaint?
Did the -- did the Court intimate whether it would entertain the motion of that kind or not?

turn.speaker: robert_w_ginnane
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Ginnane
turn.text: I don't want to make an erroneous statement here, but I don't think the Court gave very much of a response.
I would like to check that in the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_w_ginnane
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Ginnane
turn.text: If I'm in error, I would like to saw it on.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_w_ginnane
turn.label: Mr. Robert W. Ginnane
turn.text: Now, we contend that the District Court did not err in denying this motion.

Now, the appellants based their argument on Rule 15 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, which provides that after issue has been joined, a party may amend this proceeding only by leave of court or by written consent of the adverse party and leave shall be grant -- given freely when justice so requires.
But we submit that Rule 15 is directed largely, primarily at the amendment of pleadings in connection with judicial trials.
Every one of the -- of the cases, cited by the appellants on this point, relates the amendment of pleadings in cases tried by the courts.

We are concerned, as we see it, in this situation with an amendment or pleadings in the usual sense at all, because what the appellants are trying to do here is not just a little old amendment of a pleading, It amounts to a deliberate attempt.
It's almost unique to subject administrative orders to piecemeal successive review or rolling review.
